text:
Welcome to "This is my Architecture",
Iâ€™m Lana from AWS and today

we're talking to Sandeep from JD Power.
Sandeep, welcome.

Thank you Lana.
Great having you here,

and would you mind telling us
a little bit more about JD Power.

Yeah, so JD Power is
best known for our customer satisfaction

research into new car purchases,
as well as their long-term reliability.

Today we're going to be
talking about a data lakes solution

that you've built called AI Cloud.
Would you mind explaining to us

a little bit more about how you're using
that and how would a user

interact with this system?
Sure, so before we talk about the solution,

let me talk a little bit about the problem
that we were trying to solve here.
So at JD Power every single year

we talk to hundreds of
thousands of customers,

we gather data from them,
we create benchmarks and insights

and we publish rankings.
So we work in several different industries

right so it can be an automobile survey,
or it can be a financial survey,

or it can be a utility survey.
So we do hundreds of different studies

every year and every single day
we add new surveys.

And I'm seeing that we're starting with
a web interface so is this where we ingest data?

Yes, this is where we start
by ingesting data.

So a user basically logs into
our web console here,

and is authenticated using Cognito.
So all the user information and

authentication information
is in Cognito.

So once a user is logged into the console,
you have access to the data ingestion module.

So, in the data ingestion module
you can create several connectors

to all the different sources
that we have at JD Power.

The source can be a simple RDS instance,
or it can be an S3 bucket, or it can be an FTP location,

or it can be some kind of an API.
So once you create those connections,

we use Glue to crawl through the data
that is over there and we create
catalogs and the catalog is saved in Glue.
The data itself is moved to S3 buckets.

So we're using S3
as the central location

where you can combine
all of these data sources

and have it available to run analytics,
querying and ETL workloads?

Yes, once the data is on the AI Cloud,
it's all in one place (S3 bucket).

Would you mind telling me a little bit more
about how you are using glue to create these catalogs?

Yes, so when you create the connector,
Glue is our first line of defense where

it goes and tries to crawl through those
data sources and it tries to create a catalog.

Now, most of the time it does a very good job,
but there might be

some special files like an SPS file
or some internal special format file,

so for that we have our own crawlers.
And those crawlers actually

run on top of Fargate.
So what happens is when a user logs in,

you have the ability to run
a simple Lambda function which uses

Glue out of the box,
and if Glue is not able to

look at that file and create
a catalog, then it moves on

to the Fargate instance.
- Ok, so here we have shorter running

jobs versus longer running processes,
that do have some custom code

that you're using to create a catalog.
So, let's say when we've created this new catalog

using your custom logic, does
this get stored in a different location,

or is it imported back into Glue?
- That's a very good question

so no matter if you use the Glue crawler
or our custom crawlers,
the catalog is only saved in Glue.

So Glue is the only place where all
the catalogs are saved.

Sounds great, and let's
move on to Athena and Redshift.

So, how do you differentiate
on what types of data do you use

to query with Athena vs. Redshift.
So most of our data analytical

activity or data transformation
activity happens on Athena.

So even when we try to save the initial data
onto S3 we convert that from the data

into a parquet format,
it's a columnar format,

even that activity happens on top of Athena.
Even once the data is saved in S3,

all the transformations,
all the cleaning rules happen

on top of Athena.
And we use Redshift when we

try to expose the data to
an analytical platform,
where we create dashboards.

So that's where we use Redshift,
and data moves from S3 bucket to Redshift.

- So creating a data warehouse
here that is actually fed by the data lake itself.

- Yes.
- That sounds great, and as a data scientist,

I would like to touch on how you're using
machine learning and analytics dashboards

to make my job easier.
- So we have a very large data science group

at JD Power, and they all work on the
AI Cloud platform.

And we use Fargate to create either
Jupyter Notebook, or our studio endpoints;

they just log into the console where
either the Jupyter Notebook or

our studio console is exposed,
and they create all their models on top of that.

That sounds great! Sundeep,
thank you so much for coming today

and telling us a little bit more about JD Power,
and how you're using data lakes

for your AI Cloud solution.
Thank you, Lana.

And thank you for watching
"This is my Architecture."
